posts.cooked:
We’ve been experiencing a problem with our autos where every single path we run using a pathfollower command does not execute/carry out immediately.

We ARE using the warmup command in RobotInit, we have tried the 0.01s waitcommand (neither seemed to make a difference?)

For example when it scores a gamepiece in this video , the code commands it to drive away immediately after shooting for 0.8 seconds, but it consistently waits until the elevator is almost entirely down.

Even at the start of auto or when driving to and from the feeder station, pauses happen that are not in our code.

It’s very likely we’re implementing something wrong as this is the first year we’ve tried custom autos rather than pure pathplanner but after inspecting other team’s autonomous (notably 3847, spectrum’s) our code seems to be very similar to the point where these errors don’t make sense.

Here’s a snippet of our declaration of an auto:

and our followPathCommand:

and the codebase for good measure

I’m on my phone right now so I can’t do any detailed analysis, but this area would likely be your culprit (im LimelightAutoCmd ):

Without necessarily stepping inside each function, it looks as if it’s resetting the timer when the elevator reaches L4, meaning that it will end 0.8 seconds after the elevator reaches that point.

For future reference, I would highly recommend looking into Command Compositions rather than C-style subroutines. It should generally create cleaner commands and make things a little simpler to debug.

link_counts.title: Command Compositions — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked:
Thanks for the reply, but it most definitely isn’t. We’ve logged thru each step of auto and it exits LimelightAutoCmd properly, that timer is supposed to reset when the elevator is in position. It makes sure we shoot for long enough that the coral clears the wheels

And it doesn’t explain this

Even at the start of auto or when driving to and from the feeder station, pauses happen that are not in our code.

Are you seeing loop overruns when these delays happen? Is there high RoboRIO CPU utilization?

In terms of debugging, in each command’s end and initialize methods, print something to the console and take note of any delays. That should help narrow down where it actually is. Loop overruns will also be easier to track since you can see during which command it occurs.

we’ve looked through the log files and there’s no overruns or abnormal spikes in voltage/cpu

we do log the auto step to the console and it updates as expected, I examined the autostep logging to see if that was the problem but removing it changed nothing:

Try logging the timestamp as well (or the elapsed time from a timer) in those commands–both in initialize and end . This can help you see if it happens between commands or if one particular command is taking too long.

posts.name: Adam Bochek
posts.cooked:
Adding a conclusion for anyone searching in the future.

The mid auto pauses where our fault,  logic in the code was wrong. @crueter was right about those in his initial posts.

The pause at the beginning of auto still is occurring after a fresh boot or deploy.   This seems to be related to this thread from spectrum.

The drive train seems to have a significant delay at the beginning of auto, and when it does start moving pathplanner is commanding a larger then expected initial velocity.

You can see in the following image two runs of the same path, the first run is after a deploy, the robot is then driven back to the starting location in teleop and a second run is made.

Adding a small (0.1s) delay as the first command in the auto seems to have resolved this issue.  We are still seeing a delay of about 400-500ms between auto starting and the drive train moving, but the movement is smooth and the robot starts with a “as expected” initial velocity.

As this concern is no longer the lowest hanging fruit to accomplishing our goals this season we’re not going to spend any more time debugging the delay.

Hopefully this helps someone in the future!

link_counts.title: PathPlanner Initial Lag after Deploying Code

posts.cooked:
The real problem was in setting all the drivetrain motors to brake mode on disabledExit()

450ms delay on enable -- Do you have this issue too? Programming
